Question_1.Context: Radiohybrid PSMA-targeted ligands have been developed for theranostic applications in prostate cancer, aiming for optimized binding, reduced charge, and accelerated kidney excretion.
Question_1.Question: What is the primary reason for developing radiohybrid PSMA-targeted ligands?
Question_1.A: To increase the half-life of the ligands in the bloodstream
Question_1.B: To provide an optimized binding profile to human serum albumin and accelerated kidney excretion
Question_1.C: To enhance the visual contrast in imaging applications
Question_1.D: To increase the overall negative charge of the ligands
Question_1.Source: Radiohybrid PSMA-targeted ligands (rhPSMA) have been introduced as a novel platform for theranostic applications. Among a variety of rhPSMA-ligands developed for radioligand therapy, two stereoisomers [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 and -10.2 have been synthesized and initially characterized in preclinical experiments with the aim to provide an optimized binding profile to human serum albumin, a reduction of charge, and thus accelerated kidney excretion.

Question_2.Context: In the development of radioligand therapy, the pharmacokinetics of ligands are crucial, particularly their uptake and excretion rates in healthy versus tumor-bearing organisms.
Question_2.Question: What is a desirable characteristic of a radioligand used in therapy for its pharmacokinetics?
Question_2.A: High uptake and slow excretion from healthy organs
Question_2.B: Low uptake and slow excretion from tumors
Question_2.C: High uptake in tumors and fast clearance from healthy organs
Question_2.D: Uniform uptake in both tumors and healthy organs
Question_2.Source: As both isomers showed similar in vitro characteristics and tumor uptake at 24 h post injection in tumor bearing mice and in order to identify the isomer with the most favorable pharmacokinetics for radioligand therapy, we carried out in-depth biodistribution and dosimetry studies in tumor-bearing and healthy mice.

Question_3.Context: Radiolabeled ligands are used in the detection and treatment of diseases, and their stability in various media is an important aspect of their effectiveness.
Question_3.Question: Why is the stability of radiolabeled ligands in different media important?
Question_3.A: To ensure they can be stored for long periods before use
Question_3.B: To guarantee they maintain their charge in different environments
Question_3.C: To ensure they remain effective during the time needed for diagnostic or therapeutic procedures
Question_3.D: To increase their visibility under imaging techniques
Question_3.Source: rhPSMA-10.1 and -10.2 were radiolabeled with lutetium-177 according to the established procedures of other DOTA-based PSMA ligands and displayed a high and comparable stability in all buffers and human serum (> 97%, 24 h).

Question_4.Context: The use of stereoisomers in the development of radioligands can result in different in vivo behaviors, which is significant for their application in radioligand therapy.
Question_4.Question: What impact can the stereoconfiguration of a radioligand have on its in vivo behavior?
Question_4.A: It can change the color of the radioligand in imaging
Question_4.B: It can affect the radioligand's stability in vitro only
Question_4.C: It can influence the radioligand's binding characteristics and in vivo pharmacokinetics
Question_4.D: It has no impact; all stereoisomers behave identically in vivo
Question_4.Source: Distinctive differences were found in the kidneys, where [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 displayed lower initial uptake and faster excretion kinetics compared to [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.2 expressed by a 1.5-fold and ninefold lower uptake value at 1 h and 24 h in healthy animals, respectively.

Question_5.Context: In radioligand therapy, the dosimetry studies involve calculating the radiation doses delivered to various organs to assess the potential risks and therapeutic benefits.
Question_5.Question: What is the purpose of performing dosimetry studies in the context of radioligand therapy?
Question_5.A: To determine the colorimetric properties of the radioligand
Question_5.B: To calculate the radiation doses delivered to organs and tissues
Question_5.C: To measure the electrical conductivity of the radioligand in tissues
Question_5.D: To assess the magnetic properties of the radioligand
Question_5.Source: For estimating tumor doses the unit density sphere model described by Stabin and Konijnenberg (2000) was utilized.

Question_6.Context: The development of radioligands for prostate cancer treatment involves targeting the prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) to deliver therapeutic radiation specifically to cancer cells.
Question_6.Question: What is the target molecule for radioligands developed for prostate cancer treatment?
Question_6.Source: Radiohybrid PSMA-targeted ligands (rhPSMA) have been introduced as a novel platform for theranostic applications.

Question_7.Context: The use of lutetium-177 in radioligand therapy is based on its radioactive properties, which allow it to be used for both imaging and treatment purposes.
Question_7.Question: Why is lutetium-177 used in radioligand therapy?
Question_7.A: Because it has a long half-life suitable for extended imaging sessions
Question_7.B: Because it emits visible light detectable by standard imaging equipment
Question_7.C: Because it is a stable isotope that does not decay
Question_7.D: Because it emits radiation that can be used for both imaging and therapeutic purposes
Question_7.Source: rhPSMA-10.1 and -10.2 were radiolabeled with lutetium-177 according to the established procedures of other DOTA-based PSMA ligands.

Question_8.Context: The clearance rate of a radioligand from the kidneys is an important factor in its pharmacokinetic profile, as it affects the potential for renal toxicity.
Question_8.Question: Why is the kidney clearance rate of a radioligand important in its pharmacokinetic profile?
Question_8.A: A faster clearance rate indicates higher toxicity to the kidneys
Question_8.B: A slower clearance rate enhances the imaging quality of the radioligand
Question_8.C: A faster clearance rate minimizes potential renal toxicity
Question_8.D: The clearance rate has no impact on the pharmacokinetic profile
Question_8.Source: Distinctive differences were found in the kidneys, where [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 displayed lower initial uptake and faster excretion kinetics compared to [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.2.

Question_9.Context: In the context of radioligand therapy, the tumor-to-organ ratio is an important metric that reflects the specificity and potential efficacy of the radioligand.
Question_9.Question: What does a high tumor-to-organ ratio indicate in the context of radioligand therapy?
Question_9.A: The radioligand is more toxic to healthy organs than to the tumor
Question_9.B: The radioligand is non-specific and binds equally to tumors and healthy organs
Question_9.C: The radioligand has a high specificity and potential efficacy against the tumor
Question_9.D: The radioligand is likely to be rapidly excreted from the body
Question_9.Source: [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 shows fast kidney clearance kinetics resulting in excellent tumor-to-organ ratios over a therapy relevant time course.

Question_10.Context: The binding affinity of a radioligand to its target is a critical factor that influences its uptake in tumor cells and its effectiveness in radioligand therapy.
Question_10.Question: Why is the binding affinity of a radioligand to its target important?
Question_10.A: A higher binding affinity usually correlates with higher uptake in target cells and increased therapeutic effectiveness
Question_10.B: A lower binding affinity is preferred to ensure rapid clearance from the body
Question_10.C: Binding affinity is only relevant for imaging purposes and not for therapy
Question_10.D: Binding affinity affects the color of the radioligand in imaging
Question_10.Source: In a preclinical selection process of rhPSMA-7 isomers which are different in the stereoconfiguration of a Diaminopropionic acid unit (D-Dap or L-Dap) and the chelator (R-DOTAGA or S-DOTAGA), rhPSMA-7.3 (D-Dap, S-DOTAGA) displayed superior tumor uptake and faster clearance from background organs, compared with other isomers.
